docs.lead_paragraph: WEST CALIFORNIA: SECOND OFFICER PLEADS GUILTY -- A second Los Angeles policeman has agreed to a plea deal and will help an investigation of abuses at an antigang unit. The officer, Nino Durden, said he and his partner had shot an unarmed, handcuffed gang member. He pleaded guilty to state charges and is expected to receive nearly eight years in prison. James Sterngold (NYT) ROCKIES COLORADO: COYOTES ARE SPARED -- Lawmakers killed a plan to shoot coyotes in western Colorado to see if they were responsible for a decline in mule deer. The Division of Wildlife had proposed the shootings because the state's deer population, roughly 545,000, is about 90,000 fewer than desired. Environmentalists had criticized the plan as a concession to hunters. (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: After a 7-year-old boy complained to his teacher in February about welts on his back, Georgia child welfare authorities were surprised to discover that the beating had taken place not at his home but at services in his church, a tiny nondenominational congregation called the House of Prayer, northwest of downtown. And the boy was not alone, a state investigation concluded. Welfare authorities said nearly 60 children had been seriously beaten by their parents and by church leaders, under the supervision of the Rev. Arthur Allen Jr., the pastor. Several children had open wounds, large bruises and welts, investigators said.

headline.main: Child Abuse at a Church Creates a Stir in Atlanta

docs.abstract: Welfare authorities in Atlanta say 60 children have been seriously beaten by their parents and by church leaders, under supervision of Rev Arthur Allen Jr, pastor of tiny nondenominational congregation called House of Prayer; Chief Judge Sanford Jones reluctantly orders 41 children into foster care when parents refuse to stop using belts and switches to beat their children; parents say they are raising children according to Bible, and Rev Allen says court is trying to impose white standards on black church; Allen was jailed for 30 days in 1993 after ordering 16-year-old girl to be whipped with belts for half hour; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Black people need therapy, too,'' says Aunt Lily (Jacqui Parker) in ''Lift,'' a feature by the directors DeMane Davis and Khari Streeter that is filled with similar gems that drop out of nowhere. To be shown tonight at 6 and Saturday at 3 p.m. as part of the New Directors/New Films festival at the Museum of Modern Art, ''Lift'' focuses on Niecy (Kerry Washington), a sharp-eyed young African-American woman. Niecy does a high-wire act between two cultures -- her inner-city Boston neighborhood and Kennedy's, the upscale department store where she works -- with ease; at the job, her dimples are constantly flexed.

headline.main: A Severe Case of Sticky Fingers (and Tunnel Vision)

docs.abstract: Elvis Mitchell reviews Lift, Film by DeMane Davis and Khari Streeter film to be shown as part of New Directors/ New Films festival at Museum of Modern Art; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MIDWAY through her first pregnancy, Kelly Ripa, then recognizable to soap opera fans as ''All My Children's'' oft-victimized Hayley Vaughan (damaged goods! always bawling!) and currently enjoying heightened celebrity as Regis Philbin's vivacious new co-host (sole survivor of a grueling 67-contestant star search!), was out strolling, bloated but not freakishly so, when a passer-by zoomed in for an unsolicited Upper West Side eyewitness critique. Ms. Ripa always did project an aura of vulnerability (back in Berlin, N.J., she was the classmate everybody teased ''mercilessly''). ''You're having a girl!'' the woman bellowed. ''And the reason you're so ugly is because she's sucking the beauty out of you,'' she added in a burst of constructive criticism.

headline.main: Juggling Pregnancy, Jitters, Soap Career and Regis

docs.abstract: Public Lives column profiles career of Kelly Ripa, who discusses juggling family life with role in soap opera All My Children and co-host of Live With Regis and Kelly; photo (M)
